faqs.question: What is the typical size range for a residential plot for sale in Sector 1
faqs.answer: Residential plots in Sector 1 Gurugram typically range from smaller 4 Marla options which are around 108 square yards up to large 14 Marla plots which are approximately 378 square yards or more. The availability varies based on the specific micro-location within the sector and whether the plot is part of a planned scheme or an independent land parcel. We advise consulting our listings which provide exact dimensions in square yards and feet, allowing you to choose the size that perfectly accommodates your intended construction and budget constraints.

faqs.question: Are there any specific building height or floor restrictions in Sector 1 Gurugram plots
faqs.answer: Yes, building construction on a plot for sale in Sector 1 is governed by the Haryana Building Code and local municipal corporation guidelines. Generally, residential plots are permitted to construct up to four independent floor units plus a basement and stilt parking, depending on the plot size and local Floor Area Ratio FAR norms. It is essential to confirm the specific FSI Floor Space Index applicable to your chosen plot before finalising the architectural plans to ensure compliance and avoid future regulatory issues.

faqs.question: What documentation is required to purchase a plot for sale in Sector 1
faqs.answer: The essential documents include the registered Sale Deed or Conveyance Deed, mutation papers reflecting current ownership, the latest property tax receipts, and a no-objection certificate NOC if required for specific utilities. We also recommend checking the official Sector Layout Plan to ensure the plot boundaries are accurate. Our legal team assists buyers in verifying all necessary paperwork and ensuring the transition of title is legally sound and complete.

faqs.question: Can non-residents or NRIs buy a plot for sale in Sector 1 Gurugram
faqs.answer: Yes, Non-Resident Indians NRIs and Persons of Indian Origin PIOs are permitted to purchase immovable property, including residential plots, in India, subject to the provisions of the Foreign Exchange Management Act FEMA. The purchasing process is similar to resident Indians, though funds must be routed through NRE Non-Resident External or NRO Non-Resident Ordinary accounts.
